10:00 – 21:30
✨ Highlights
🛍️ Discount Heaven: international brands (Nike, Adidas, Coach, Michael Kors, etc.) with year-round sales.
👗 Fashion + Lifestyle: clothes, shoes, bags, cosmetics, and homeware.
🍴 Food Court & Cafés: Chinese and Western dining, good for shopping breaks.
🎉 Seasonal Promotions: big events during holidays—Black Friday, 11.11, Spring Festival sales.
📸 Social Media Favorites: shopping bags piled up, outlet street design, and group shopping selfies.
👥 Best For
Shoppers hunting for bargains 🛍️
Families (spacious + dining options) 👨‍👩‍👧
Young travelers who want outlet deals ✨
Group trips (friends shopping together) 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Xiasha (江干区东部), about 40–50 min from downtown by car/metro.
🚇 Metro Line 1 → Jiubao or Wenze Road Station → short taxi ride.
💸 Plan 3–4 hours—outlet is big, with lots of brands.
🌅 Best time: weekday afternoons (less crowded).
🛍️ Join membership for extra discounts & coupons.

column2: Hubin Yintai in77 (湖滨银泰 in77)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
💸 100–300 RMB/person (dining & shopping average)
Luxury shopping can go much higher 🛍️
🕒 Opening Hours
10:00 – 22:00
✨ Highlights
🏙 Hangzhou’s Fashion Hub: luxury brands (LV, Gucci, Prada), designer boutiques, and trendy lifestyle stores.
🍴 Food Paradise: from Michelin-starred restaurants to local Hangzhou fusion and stylish cafés.
🌆 West Lake + City Mix: just steps away from West Lake, blending shopping with lakeside walks.
🌙 Night Lights: in77’s neon facades + nearby lakeside light shows = photogenic nightlife.
📸 Social Media Favorites: luxury storefronts, rooftop cafés, neon reflections, and West Lake sunsets from nearby.
👥 Best For
Shoppers 🛍️ (luxury + trendy brands)
Couples (romantic dinner + lakeside stroll) 💕
Young travelers looking for “city lifestyle” ✨
Content creators (lots of photogenic city corners) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located at Hubin area, walking distance to West Lake & Lakeside Pedestrian Street.
🍵 Perfect to combine with a West Lake night walk for a “shopping + scenery” experience.
💸 Dining options vary: cheap bites in the mall food court, or fine dining in luxury restaurants.
🌅 Best time: evening—shop, have dinner, then watch the West Lake night lights.
🚇 Metro Line 1 → Longxiangqiao Station (龙翔桥站), right at the mall.

column2: Shengli River Food Street (胜利河美食街)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
💸 80–150 RMB/person (restaurants & river fish dishes)
💸 Street snacks & beer ~30–60 RMB/person
🕒 Opening Hours
10:00 – 23:00 （dinner & night most lively 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🍲 Hangzhou-Style Dining: famous for river fish, shrimp, and traditional Hangzhou dishes.
🍺 Nightlife Vibes: popular night spot for locals to eat, drink, and hang out by the river.
🏮 Street Ambience: lined with restaurants, bars, and teahouses—lantern-lit nights feel festive.
🌆 Local Favorite: less touristy than Hefang Street, more for locals and food lovers.
📸 Social Media Favorites: steaming hotpots, outdoor riverfront seating, neon restaurant signs.
👥 Best For
Foodies 🍜
Friends gathering or group dining 🍻
Couples (romantic riverside dinner) 💕
Travelers who want authentic Hangzhou food scene 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near the Grand Canal, Gongshu District.
🍴 Must-try: river fish in soy sauce, stir-fried shrimp, Hangzhou-style crayfish (seasonal).
🌙 Best time: after 18:00 for dinner + drinks.
💸 Some restaurants can be pricey—check menus before entering.
🚶 Combine with nearby Xiaohe Straight Street for a canal-side stroll after dinner.

column2: Cangqian Night Market (余杭仓前夜市)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
Street food: 10–25 RMB/dish
Shopping: 20–100 RMB for small items
🕒 Opening Hours
18:00 – 23:30 （weekends最热闹 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🍢 Foodie Heaven: skewers, fried chicken, stinky tofu, grilled squid, bubble tea—local students’ favorites.
👗 Trendy Vibes: lots of stalls selling cheap fashion, accessories, and quirky gadgets.
🎉 Youthful Energy: near university area, full of students, super lively and social.
🌆 Local Hangout: not touristy, a true “where locals go at night” experience.
📸 Social Media Favorites: neon food stalls, long barbecue lines, bubble tea cups with glowing lights.
👥 Best For
Young travelers & students ✨
Foodies on a budget 🍜
Travelers seeking non-touristy nightlife 🌙
Groups of friends wanting a casual evening 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Yuhang District, ~40 min drive/metro from Hangzhou downtown (near universities & Alibaba Xixi area).
🌙 Best to visit after 19:00 for peak vibes.
💸 Cashless payments only (WeChat/Alipay).
👟 Market gets crowded—wear comfy shoes and be ready for a lot of walking.
🍴 Must-try: grilled skewers, milk tea, fried buns, and late-night spicy snacks.

column2: Fengqi Farmers’ Market (凤起农贸市场)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
Groceries & snacks: 10–50 RMB
Casual meals: 20–80 RMB/person
🕒 Opening Hours
06:00 – 20:00 （morning最热闹 🌞）
✨ Highlights
🥬 Local Life Window: fresh vegetables, fruits, meat, seafood—true everyday Hangzhou.
🍜 Hidden Food Stalls: noodle shops, dumplings, soy milk & fried dough sticks—breakfast heaven.
🐟 Seafood & River Fish: live fish, shrimp, and Hangzhou specialties (great if you want to cook or just watch).
🛍️ Trendy Market Upgrade: not just raw food—lots of small eateries, bakeries, and chic stalls appear here too.
📸 Social Media Favorites: colorful produce displays, steaming bowls of noodles, and candid shots of local vendors.
👥 Best For
Foodies & market lovers 🍜
Travelers seeking “real local life” 🌱
Photographers (colorful & lively atmosphere) 📷
Early risers who love exploring markets 🌞
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located downtown near Fengqi Road, easy to reach by metro.
🌅 Best to go in the morning (6:00–9:00) to feel the bustle & try local breakfast.
🍴 Must-try: Hangzhou noodles (片儿川), dumplings, fried buns, and fresh soy milk.
🛍️ Great spot to buy local snacks/ingredients if staying in an Airbnb.
👟 Market can be crowded—wear comfy shoes and prepare for some “organized chaos.”

column2: Damalong Historical Street (大马弄历史街区)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to stroll 🎉 （local snacks & meals ~20–60 RMB/person）
🕒 Opening Hours
10:00 – 22:00 （夜晚最热闹 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🏘 Authentic Local Vibes: compared with Hefang Street, Damalong is less touristy, more for locals.
🍜 Foodie Street: full of small eateries, noodle shops, dumpling stalls, and traditional Hangzhou snacks.
🏮 Historic Ambience: narrow alleys, brick houses, and a mix of old and new businesses.
🌆 Night Market Energy: evenings bring neon lights, bustling food stalls, and neighborhood buzz.
📸 Social Media Favorites: steaming noodle bowls, neon-lit alleys, and retro-style shopfronts.
👥 Best For
Foodies who want “real Hangzhou” flavors 🍜
Young travelers who love street culture ✨
Locals & repeat visitors (non-touristy vibe) 🚶
Photographers (street food + local life) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Shangcheng District, not far from Wushan Square.
🍴 Must-try: Hangzhou-style noodles (片儿川), dumplings, grilled skewers, and late-night snacks.
🌙 Best to go after 18:00 for the fullest atmosphere.
💸 Prices are much cheaper than tourist streets like Hefang.
👟 Street is narrow and crowded—wear comfy shoes.

column2: Hefang Street Food (河坊街美食 / Hefang Street Snacks)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
💸 20–50 RMB/person for street snacks
💸 80–150 RMB/person if dining in sit-down restaurants
🕒 Opening Hours
10:00 – 22:00 （evenings最热闹 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🍢 Snack Heaven: stinky tofu, fried buns, scallion pancakes, grilled squid, and tanghulu (candied hawthorn).
🍵 Hangzhou Classics: Beggar’s Chicken (叫花鸡), West Lake Vinegar Fish (西湖醋鱼), and Longjing Shrimp (龙井虾仁).
🏮 Historic Atmosphere: street lined with Qing-style architecture, red lanterns, and tea houses.
🌆 Night Market Vibes: evenings are full of sizzling woks, neon-lit stalls, and tourist crowds.
📸 Social Media Favorites: tanghulu skewers, steaming skewers, traditional shopfronts lit at night.
👥 Best For
Foodies 🍜
First-time visitors (must-try cultural street) 🌏
Families & groups 👨‍👩‍👧
Content creators (lots of photogenic snacks) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near Wushan Square & Southern Song Imperial Street.
🌙 Best time: evening when the street is buzzing.
🍢 Must-try snacks: stinky tofu, sugar painting (糖画), fried stinky tofu stuffed buns, and Hangzhou desserts.
💸 Street food is cheap; restaurants are more tourist-priced.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—the street gets crowded, especially on weekends.

column2: Wulin Night Market (武林夜市)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉 （street food 10–30 RMB / dish; fashion & accessories 30–200 RMB）
🕒 Opening Hours
18:00 – 23:00 （most lively around 19:00–22:00）
✨ Highlights
🍢 Trendy Street Food: skewers, bubble tea, fried chicken, stinky tofu, grilled seafood—young locals’ favorites.
👗 Youth Fashion Bazaar: cheap & chic clothes, jewelry, makeup, and quirky accessories.
🌆 Lively City Vibes: located near Wulin Square & downtown malls—night shopping + night snacking combo.
🎭 Modern + Local Mix: compared to Wushan Night Market, it’s trendier, with more student crowds.
📸 Social Media Favorites: neon-lit food stalls, bubble tea selfies, and colorful accessory stands.
👥 Best For
Young travelers & students ✨
Foodies on a budget 🍜
Night shoppers (clothes, trinkets, streetwear) 👗
Groups of friends looking for casual nightlife 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in downtown near Wulin Square—super convenient if staying central.
🍴 Go after dinner for snacks + browsing.
💸 Bargaining possible for accessories/clothes, less so for food.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—narrow aisles can get crowded.
🌅 Combine with a daytime mall trip (Intime, Hangzhou Tower) for a full shopping day.

column2: Wushan Night Market (吴山夜市)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to enter 🎉 （street food 10–30 RMB / dish, small items 20–100 RMB）
🕒 Opening Hours
18:00 – 23:00 （best time 19:00–21:30）
✨ Highlights
🍢 Street Food Paradise: skewers, stinky tofu, dumplings, grilled seafood—classic Hangzhou night flavors.
🛍️ Cheap & Fun Shopping: clothes, accessories, toys, phone cases—bargain hunters’ heaven.
🌆 Local Vibes: less touristy than Hefang Street, more down-to-earth and lively.
🎭 Nightlife Atmosphere: neon lights, crowded stalls, vendors shouting—it’s the “real city night” side of Hangzhou.
📸 Social Media Favorites: colorful food stalls, skewers sizzling on the grill, crowds under neon signs.
👥 Best For
Foodies 🍜
Nightlife lovers 🌙
Young travelers & groups of friends ✨
Anyone curious about Hangzhou’s local street culture 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near Wushan Square & Hefang Street—easy to combine in a City Walk.
💸 Bargaining is possible for non-food items (accessories, clothes).
🍢 Must-try: grilled skewers, stinky tofu, and fried dumplings.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—it gets crowded.
🌅 Best to go after dinner for snacks & shopping atmosphere.

column2: Hangzhou Gate (杭州之门)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to view 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours （夜景最推荐 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🌆 Futuristic Landmark: twin towers forming a giant “arch,” symbolizing the gateway to Hangzhou’s future.
🌙 Night Lights: dazzling LED displays on the towers—skyline centerpiece of Qianjiang New Town.
📸 Photo Hotspot: often compared to Shanghai’s Lujiazui and Beijing’s CBD skyline, but with Hangzhou’s unique vibe.
🌉 Modern Skyline Vibes: located by Qiantang River, surrounded by Grand Theatre, City Balcony, and Century Park.
🎇 Events & Festivals: light shows synchronized with the city’s skyline during holidays.
👥 Best For
Couples (romantic skyline walk 💕)
Photographers & IG creators 📷
Travelers wanting to see Hangzhou’s “modern face” 🌆
Nightlife explorers 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Qianjiang New Town CBD, easily reached by Metro Line 4 (Citizen Center Station).
🌅 Best time: sunset → night, when towers light up and skyline reflections appear on the river.
🧺 Great spot for night walks combined with City Balcony & Qianjiang Century Park.
📱 Bring wide-angle lens or drone for the full arch effect.
🍴 Plenty of restaurants & malls nearby—ideal for dinner + night view combo.

column2: Hangzhou Grand Theatre (杭州大剧院)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to view from outside 🎉
Performances: 80–500+ RMB (depending on show type & seating)
🕒 Opening Hours
Exterior & square: 24 hours
Box office & shows: usually 10:00 – 21:30 （depending on schedule）
✨ Highlights
🎭 Cultural Landmark: designed by Canadian architect Carlos Ott, shaped like a futuristic glass dome.
🌆 Iconic Riverside Location: sits on the Qiantang River, facing Hangzhou’s modern skyline.
🎶 Diverse Performances: opera, ballet, symphony, musicals, and Chinese traditional shows.
🌙 Night Illumination: theatre glows in changing colors, reflecting in the river—perfect nightscape.
📸 Social Media Favorites: glass dome at sunset, colorful night reflections, panoramic drone shots with skyline.
👥 Best For
Art & theatre lovers 🎭
Couples (romantic night show + riverside walk) 💕
Photographers (architectural & nightscape shots) 📷
Travelers exploring modern Hangzhou 🌆
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Qianjiang New Town, near City Balcony & Qianjiang Century Park.
🎫 Book tickets online in advance (WeChat/Alipay apps or theatre’s official site).
🌅 Best time: arrive before sunset → photos outside → enjoy evening performance.
👟 Combine with a riverside City Walk for best experience.
🍴 Dining: plenty of restaurants in nearby MixC Mall & Raffles City.

column2: Hangzhou City Balcony (杭州城市阳台)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours （夜景最推荐 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🌊 Riverside Landmark: iconic riverside square in Qianjiang New Town, right by the Qiantang River.
🌆 Modern Hangzhou Vibes: surrounded by Hangzhou Grand Theatre, International Conference Center, and futuristic skyscrapers.
🌙 Light Shows & Night Views: dazzling skyline lights reflect on the river—super popular for evening walks.
🎇 Events & Fireworks: main stage for festivals, concerts, and National Day celebrations.
📸 Social Media Favorites: riverside boardwalk, illuminated theatre dome, skyline shots with Qiantang River.
👥 Best For
Couples (romantic night walk 💕)
Families 👨‍👩‍👧 (safe, open space for kids to run)
Photographers (best nightscape shots in Hangzhou) 📷
Travelers who want to see “modern Hangzhou” beyond West Lake 🌆
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Metro Line 4 → Citizen Center (市民中心站), then short walk.
🌅 Best time: sunset → nightfall for skyline light shows.
🧺 Great spot for casual hangouts or riverside picnics.
🎫 Free entry, but avoid big events if you don’t like crowds.
🍴 Plenty of dining options in MixC Mall & Raffles City nearby.

column2: Yohoo Park (玉湖公园)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours （夜晚湖边散步也很适合 🌙）
✨ Highlights
🌊 Urban Lake Oasis: a large artificial lake surrounded by greenways, lawns, and modern landscaping.
🚶 Perfect for Strolls & Jogging: wide lakefront paths with bridges, pavilions, and seasonal flowers.
🌇 Sunset Views: lake reflections of the skyline are especially photogenic.
🌿 Family-Friendly: playgrounds, picnic areas, and open lawns for kids and weekend hangouts.
📸 Social Media Favorites: lake-and-skyline reflections, boardwalks, and evening light ambience.
👥 Best For
Families 👨‍👩‍👧 (kids-friendly)
Couples 💕 (romantic lakeside walk)
Joggers, cyclists & casual strollers 🚴
Locals & travelers wanting a quiet urban escape 🌱
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Qianjiang Century City (near Hangzhou Olympic Sports Center, Xiaoshan District).
🚇 Take Metro Line 2 to Qianjiang Century City Station, then short walk/taxi.
🌅 Best time: late afternoon → sunset → evening stroll.
🧺 Bring snacks/drinks for a mini picnic—lots of lawns.
🌸 Seasonal flowers around the park make spring and autumn especially beautiful.

column2: Qianjiang Century Park (钱江世纪公园)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours （夜景特别推荐 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🌆 CBD Green Lung: the largest urban park in Hangzhou’s Qianjiang New Town, surrounded by futuristic skyscrapers.
🌙 Night Lights: dazzling skyline views with light shows on the “Sun and Moon Twin Towers” and other landmarks.
🚶 City Walk Vibes: broad lawns, fountains, and riverside promenades—perfect for evening strolls.
🎇 Events & Festivals: often hosts concerts, light shows, and public celebrations (like National Day fireworks).
📸 Social Media Favorites: skyline reflections in the fountain pool, city lights at night, drone shots of the park + CBD.
👥 Best For
Couples (romantic night walk 💕)
Friends & families on chill evenings 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers & IG creators 📷
Travelers wanting to see Hangzhou’s modern face 🌆
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Qianjiang New Town (钱江新城), easily reachable by Metro Line 2 or 4.
🌅 Best time: after sunset—the skyline light show is the highlight.
🧺 Great spot for picnics or casual hangouts on the grass.
🎇 Check event schedules—during holidays, the park gets super lively.
🍴 Plenty of malls & restaurants nearby (like MixC Mall) for dining before/after.

column2: Archaeological Ruins of Liangzhu Ancient City (良渚古城遗址)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
80 RMB (includes Liangzhu Museum + core ruins area shuttle bus)
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🏺 UNESCO World Heritage Site: recognized as proof of over 5,000 years of Chinese civilization.
🌾 Ancient Water System: large-scale dams and canals show advanced prehistoric engineering.
🎨 Jade Civilization: Liangzhu people were masters of jade carving—ritual jades are iconic treasures.
🏯 Liangzhu Museum: stunning modern architecture + immersive exhibitions about ancient city life.
📸 Social Media Favorites: jade artifacts in the museum, panoramic shots of the ancient city site, futuristic museum building in nature.
👥 Best For
History & archaeology lovers 🏛️
Culture seekers who want to see “China’s 5,000-year civilization” 🌏
Families with kids interested in ancient life 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers (museum architecture + open ruins) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 1 hour drive from Hangzhou downtown—best to book a half-day or day trip.
🎫 Ticket includes shuttle bus between museum and ruins site—save energy by using it.
🌸 Best season: spring & autumn for outdoor site exploration.
🧢 Bring hat/water in summer—ruins area has limited shade.
📚 Recommended to visit the Liangzhu Museum first → then explore the ruins, for context.

column2: Dadou Road Historic Block (大兜路历史街区)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to stroll 🎉 （dining & shopping extra）
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (shops & restaurants usually 10:00 – 22:00)
✨ Highlights
🏘 Canal-Side Heritage: old houses and warehouses along the Beijing–Hangzhou Grand Canal, now transformed into a lively leisure district.
🍴 Foodie Heaven: Hangzhou snacks, river fish dishes, cafés, and stylish restaurants.
🎨 Old Meets New: historic architecture fused with creative spaces, boutique shops, and bars.
🌙 Nightlife Vibes: lantern-lit streets and canal reflections make evenings especially atmospheric.
📸 Social Media Favorites: canal bridges at sunset, rustic stone walls, neon-lit restaurants at night.
👥 Best For
Foodies 🍜
Couples (romantic night stroll) 💕
Friends & groups looking for dining + drinks ✨
Travelers who want both culture & lifestyle 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Gongshu District, near Gongchen Bridge & other canal museums.
🌅 Best time: evening—perfect for food, lights, and canal night views.
🍺 Great place to try river fish dishes & hang out at bars after dinner.
🚶 Not very big—1–2 hours is enough unless you stop for food/drinks.
📍 Can combine with Xiaohe Straight Street or the Grand Canal Museum for a half-day canal trip.

column2: Xiaohe Straight Street (小河直街)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to stroll 🎉 （food & drinks extra）
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (cafés & shops usually 10:00 – 21:00)
✨ Highlights
🏘 Canal-Side Old Street: preserved traditional houses and stone pavements along the Grand Canal.
🍵 Cultural + Lifestyle Mix: teahouses, cafés, art shops, and boutique B&Bs line the street.
🌿 Slow Vibes: compared to Hefang Street, it’s quieter, more authentic, with local Hangzhou life.
🎨 Art & Crafts: small galleries, cultural shops, and occasional exhibitions.
📸 Social Media Favorites: canal reflections, rustic teahouses, and evening lantern-lit streets.
👥 Best For
Slow travelers 🌱
Couples (romantic stroll + canal-side cafés) 💕
Photographers (sunset + water reflections) 📷
Travelers looking for authentic Hangzhou local life 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located north of downtown, about 20 min from West Lake by car.
🚶 Best explored on foot; short but atmospheric.
🌅 Sunset is the most photogenic time—lights + canal views.
🍴 Try local snacks or have tea in one of the canal-view cafés.
🏨 Staying in a canal-side guesthouse is a unique option for slow travelers.

column2: Songcheng Park (宋城)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
330 RMB (adult ticket, includes main show)
Discounts for kids/online booking
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 21:30 （depending on show schedule）
✨ Highlights
🎭 “Romance of the Song Dynasty” Show: one of China’s top-rated live performances, combining dance, acrobatics, and hi-tech stage effects.
🏯 Song Dynasty Town: streets, shops, and performances recreate Southern Song daily life.
👘 Immersive Experiences: costume rentals, parades, street shows, and folk activities.
🎨 Interactive Fun: haunted houses, folk arts, love-themed attractions—something for all ages.
📸 Social Media Favorites: Song costumes, night lanterns, and spectacular show backdrops.
👥 Best For
Families 👨‍👩‍👧 (kids love the interactive shows)
Couples 💕 (romantic night show + lantern vibes)
First-time visitors to Hangzhou (signature cultural experience)
Content creators (lots of photogenic scenes) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 30 min drive from downtown Hangzhou; shuttle buses available.
🎫 Book tickets online in advance (shows sell out on weekends/holidays).
🌙 Best time: arrive late afternoon → explore the park → watch the night show.
👘 Try Song Dynasty costumes for photos—super popular on Xiaohongshu.
🍴 Food inside is tourist-style, but fun for snacks; for serious dining, eat before or after.

column2: Xiangji Temple (香积寺)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉 (donations for incense welcome)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 17:00
✨ Highlights
🏯 Thousand-Year History: founded in the Northern Song Dynasty, once one of the “Ten Temples of the West Lake.”
🌿 Urban Zen Spot: located in Gongshu District, less touristy than Lingyin, known for its calm and authentic Buddhist atmosphere.
🍃 Vegetarian Cuisine: famous for its temple vegetarian restaurant—Hangzhou locals’ favorite for clean and creative Buddhist food.
🧘 Spiritual Rituals: chanting halls, incense rituals, and solemn courtyards bring strong Zen vibes.
📸 Social Media Favorites: golden Buddha statues, temple gate, vegetarian dishes beautifully plated.
👥 Best For
Spiritual seekers & temple lovers 🙏
Foodies curious about Buddhist vegetarian cuisine 🥗
Locals & travelers looking for a quiet cultural stop 🌿
Photographers (temple courtyards + food plating) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near the Grand Canal, can be combined with Canal-side cultural museums (Fan Museum, Umbrella Museum, etc.).
🍵 Try the temple’s vegetarian restaurant—popular and reasonably priced.
🌅 Visit in the morning for fewer people and more tranquil vibes.
🎫 Free entry, but incense & food cost extra.
👟 Easy walk inside; suitable for families and elder visitors.

column2: Jingshan Temple (径山寺)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
20 RMB (adult ticket)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 17:00
✨ Highlights
🏯 Zen Buddhism Landmark: founded in the Tang Dynasty, flourished in the Southern Song period—known as the “ancestral home of Japanese Zen.”
🍵 Origin of Tea Ceremony: the Jingshan tea ritual here influenced Japanese tea culture, making it a sacred tea site.
🌄 Mountain Serenity: located on Jingshan Mountain, surrounded by forests and tea fields—perfect Zen atmosphere.
🧘 Monastic Life: you can see monks chanting, practicing, and sometimes join short meditation activities.
📸 Social Media Favorites: mountain gate with red pillars, quiet temple halls in mist, tea fields around the temple.
👥 Best For
Spiritual seekers & Zen culture lovers 🙏
Tea enthusiasts 🍵
Photographers who enjoy mountain temples 📷
Travelers seeking a quiet, off-the-beaten-path experience 🌿
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 1 hour drive from Hangzhou downtown, best to visit by car/Didi.
🍵 Combine with nearby Jingshan tea villages for a tea + temple cultural trip.
🌅 Best in spring (tea harvest + flowers) or autumn (clear air, maple leaves).
👟 Wear comfy shoes—the temple sits on a mountain slope with many steps.
🧧 Bring some cash/Alipay for incense or tea experiences inside.

column2: Lingyin Temple (灵隐寺 / Temple of the Soul’s Retreat)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
45 RMB (Feilai Peak Scenic Area ticket, required for entry)
30 RMB (Lingyin Temple entrance ticket)
🕒 Opening Hours
07:00 – 18:00
✨ Highlights
🏯 1,600 Years of History: founded in 328 AD, one of the most famous Buddhist temples in China.
🗿 Feilai Peak Grottoes: over 300 Buddhist rock carvings, dating back to the 10th–14th centuries.
🧘 Spiritual Vibes: incense smoke, chanting monks, and solemn halls create a deeply calming atmosphere.
🌿 Scenic Location: nestled in a valley surrounded by forested peaks—perfect blend of nature + spirituality.
📸 Social Media Favorites: giant Laughing Buddha statue, incense offerings, temple gates in the mist.
👥 Best For
Spiritual seekers & culture lovers 🙏
History buffs 🏛️
Photographers who enjoy misty temples 📷
Travelers combining nature + culture in one stop 🌱
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 20 min drive from West Lake; buses and Didi available.
🎫 Buy combined ticket (Feilai Peak + Lingyin Temple).
🌅 Best time: early morning—fewer tourists, more serene.
🧧 Incense can be purchased inside; many visitors pray for health, peace, and career.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—lots of steps and walking paths around the grottoes.
🍵 Combine with Faxi Temple or tea fields nearby (Longjing Village, Meijiawu) for a cultural day trip.

column2: Hangzhou Confucius Temple (杭州孔庙)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
08:30 – 16:30
✨ Highlights
🏯 Ancient Academy: originally built in the Southern Song Dynasty, dedicated to Confucius and traditional education.
📖 Cultural Symbol: site of imperial exams and scholarly rituals, representing China’s Confucian heritage.
🌳 Peaceful Atmosphere: quiet courtyards, ancient cypress trees, and classic halls.
🎨 Elegant Architecture: stone carvings, red walls, and solemn Dacheng Hall.
📸 Social Media Favorites: stone archways, Confucius statues, and the tranquil courtyards.
👥 Best For
History & culture lovers 🏛️
Students & scholars (many visit to “pray for academic success”) ✏️
Travelers seeking a quiet, non-touristy cultural stop 🌿
Photographers who enjoy traditional architecture 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near Wushan Square & Southern Song Imperial Street—easy to combine with a cultural city walk.
🧧 Many visitors write wishes for studies, exams, or career success.
🎫 Free entry, but donations welcome.
🌅 Best visited in the morning when it’s most serene.
📚 Combine with Hangzhou Museum nearby to get a full picture of the city’s heritage.

column2: Chenghuang Pavilion (城隍阁 / City God Pavilion)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
30 RMB (adult ticket)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 21:00 （night view highly recommended 🌙✨）
✨ Highlights
🏯 Ancient-Inspired Landmark: built in traditional Chinese architectural style, with red pillars, golden eaves, and multiple tiers.
🌆 Best City + Lake Viewpoint: from the top, you get panoramic views of West Lake, Qiantang River, and Hangzhou skyline.
📖 Cultural Spot: Wu Hill (吴山) has been a Taoist site for centuries, and the pavilion continues the City God Temple tradition.
🎇 Night Lights: illuminated pavilion glowing over Hangzhou, often called “the city’s crown.”
📸 Social Media Favorites: sunset shots over West Lake, pavilion lit at night, interior murals and decorations.
👥 Best For
First-time visitors who want a “see-it-all” viewpoint 👀
Couples (romantic sunset/night lights) 💕
Photographers & IG creators 📷
Travelers combining culture + city views 🌇
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Wushan Scenic Area, near Hefang Street & Southern Song Imperial Street—easy to combine into a city walk.
🌅 Best time: go around 17:00 → enjoy sunset → stay for night lights.
👟 Some uphill walking needed, but not difficult (or take an electric cart).
🎫 Ticket includes both day and evening entry—don’t miss the night scene.
🍜 After visiting, walk down to Hefang Street for street food & night market vibes.

column2: Liuhe Pagoda (六和塔 / Six Harmonies Pagoda)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
20 RMB (entry to park)
30 RMB (extra to climb the pagoda)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:30 – 17:00
✨ Highlights
🏯 Ancient Riverside Pagoda: originally built in 970 AD during the Northern Song Dynasty, rebuilt in later dynasties.
🌊 Guardian of the Qiantang River: historically used to calm tides and guide ships.
🌅 Panoramic Views: climb to the top for sweeping views of the Qiantang River, bridges, and Hangzhou skyline.
🎨 Architectural Charm: brick-and-wood structure with intricate eaves, giving a layered “pagoda in the sky” feel.
📸 Social Media Favorites: aerial shots of the pagoda by the river, inside spiral staircases, and sunset river views.
👥 Best For
History & culture lovers 🏯
Photographers (especially at sunset) 📷
Families & travelers exploring beyond West Lake 👨‍👩‍👧
Hikers (combine with riverside walks & nearby hills) 🌿
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located ~30 min drive from West Lake, by the Qiantang River.
🌅 Best time: late afternoon → climb the tower → watch sunset over Qiantang bridges.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—stairs inside are steep and narrow.
🎫 Entry split into park + tower climb; most worth it to go up for the view.
📍 Combine with Qiantang River Bridge or Baita Park for a riverside cultural route.

column2: Southern Song Imperial Street (南宋御街 / Nansong Imperial Street)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free to stroll 🎉 （shopping & dining extra）
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (shops & restaurants usually 10:00 – 22:00)
✨ Highlights
🏯 Historic Pedestrian Street: once the central axis of the Southern Song Dynasty capital, now a lively old town street.
🛍️ Local + Tourist Mix: traditional shops, snack stalls, tea houses, and silk/souvenir boutiques.
🍜 Food Paradise: try Hangzhou must-eats like Beggar’s Chicken, West Lake vinegar fish, or street snacks.
🎭 Cultural Vibes: stone pavements, Song-style lanterns, and preserved architecture give an ancient-meets-modern feel.
📸 Social Media Favorites: night view with lanterns, traditional shops, and foodie snaps.
👥 Best For
Foodies 🍜
History & culture lovers 🏯
Families & groups 👨‍👩‍👧
Travelers who want nightlife + local vibes ✨
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Close to Hefang Street and Hangzhou Museum—easy to combine for a half-day “old Hangzhou” tour.
🌙 Best time: evening, when lights turn on and the street is most atmospheric.
💸 Bargaining is limited in most shops, but try small stalls for deals.
🍵 Don’t miss local teahouses—perfect for pairing snacks with Hangzhou tea.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—stone streets can be slippery after rain.

column2: China Knife, Scissors & Sword Museum (中国刀剪剑博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
⚔️ Unique Theme: world’s first museum fully dedicated to knives, scissors, and swords—blending utility with art.
🏯 Historic Collections: ancient bronze swords, Qing Dynasty sabers, famous Chinese scissors, and even royal ceremonial blades.
🔪 Craftsmanship Displays: showcases forging, sharpening, and decorative techniques.
🎮 Interactive Vibes: VR swordplay, multimedia displays, and weapon replicas you can pose with.
📸 Social Media Favorites: giant sword sculptures at the entrance, gleaming sword displays, and hands-on photo zones.
👥 Best For
Martial arts & history lovers ⚔️
Families with kids (lots of cool “sword & weapon” exhibits) 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers who love metallic aesthetics 📷
Travelers looking for a niche, edgy museum ✨
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Gongchen Bridge cultural cluster, next to Arts & Crafts Museum and Fan Museum—easy to combine in half a day.
🎫 Free entry; some interactive activities may charge a small fee.
⏳ Plan 1–2 hours depending on your interest.
🛍️ Small gift shop sells mini sword keychains & replicas—fun souvenirs.
🌅 End the visit with a walk along the Grand Canal & Gongchen Bridge at sunset.

column2: China Umbrella Museum (中国伞博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 16:30 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
☂️ World’s First Umbrella Museum: fully dedicated to the history, culture, and craft of umbrellas.
🎨 3,000 Years of Stories: from ancient oil-paper umbrellas to modern designs and fashion collabs.
🧵 Handmade Craftsmanship: showcases how traditional bamboo & paper umbrellas are made.
🌂 Cultural Symbolism: umbrellas in Chinese poetry, weddings, and folk traditions.
📸 Social Media Favorites: rainbow umbrella installations, elegant oil-paper umbrellas, and fan-shaped corridors.
👥 Best For
Culture & design lovers 🎨
Families with kids 👨‍👩‍👧 (colorful & fun displays)
Couples 💕 (oil-paper umbrellas are super romantic photo props)
Travelers hunting for niche museums ✨
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in the Gongchen Bridge cultural cluster (with Fan Museum, Arts & Crafts Museum, Grand Canal Museum)—perfect for half-day trip.
🎫 Free entry; sometimes has DIY umbrella-painting workshops (small fee).
⏳ 1–2 hours enough unless you join a workshop.
🛍️ Gift shop sells mini oil-paper umbrellas—cute souvenirs.
🌅 Combine with a canal-side walk & sunset at Gongchen Bridge for a full experience.

column2: China Fan Museum (中国扇博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 16:30 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🎐 World’s First Fan Museum: fully dedicated to the history and art of fans in China and beyond.
🏯 3,000+ Years of Culture: from bamboo and silk folding fans to exquisite painted & calligraphy fans.
🎨 Art + Craft: exhibitions highlight how fans combine function, painting, poetry, and handicraft.
🧵 Interactive Workshops: try painting or making your own fan—great hands-on experience.
📸 Social Media Favorites: elegant display halls, fan-shaped architecture, and handmade fan workshops.
👥 Best For
Art & culture lovers 🎨
Families with kids 👨‍👩‍👧 (fun to join DIY workshops)
Travelers looking for unique & niche cultural spots ✨
Souvenir hunters (fans are portable, authentic gifts) 🎁
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Gongchen Bridge area, next to Arts & Crafts Museum and Grand Canal Museum—perfect cluster for half-day trip.
🎫 Free entry, but workshops may charge a small fee (book on-site).
⏳ 1–2 hours recommended; allow more if joining a DIY activity.
🛍️ The museum shop sells beautiful folding fans—great souvenirs, from budget-friendly to collector’s items.
🌅 After the museum, stroll along the canal and catch sunset at Gongchen Bridge.

column2: Grand Canal Museum of Hangzhou (京杭大运河博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 16:30 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🌊 Canal Heritage: dedicated to the Beijing–Hangzhou Grand Canal, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and world’s longest man-made waterway.
🏺 Historic Exhibits: ancient canal maps, boat models, porcelain, coins, and daily life artifacts showing commerce & culture along the canal.
🚢 Maritime Vibes: immersive halls recreate canal trade scenes, old docks, and folk life in Hangzhou.
🏯 Cultural Landmark: located in Gongchen Bridge area, where history and modern canal life meet.
📸 Social Media Favorites: model boats, ancient trade murals, and photos by the iconic Gongchen Bridge.
👥 Best For
History & culture lovers 🏛️
Families (interactive canal models for kids) 👨‍👩‍👧
Travelers exploring the Canal Town vibes 🚶
Photographers who like water-town settings 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Near Gongchen Bridge, also close to China Fan Museum & Arts & Crafts Museum—perfect to combine.
🎫 Free tickets, reserve online (Alipay/WeChat mini-programs).
⏳ Plan 1–2 hours; extend to explore the canal banks & nearby creative parks.
🌅 Sunset by Gongchen Bridge is stunning—worth staying for.
🛍️ Canal area has local snack shops—try Hangzhou fried dough twists or boat-shaped rice cakes.

column2: Hangzhou Arts & Crafts Museum (杭州工艺美术博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🎨 Crafts Capital: showcases Hangzhou’s traditional handicrafts like silk weaving, fan-making, embroidery, bamboo carving, jade, porcelain, and lacquerware.
🧵 Live Demonstrations: artisans often demonstrate their craft on-site, making the visit interactive.
🏯 Cultural Cluster: located within the Crafts Museum Cluster alongside the China Knife, Scissors & Sword Museum and Fan Museum.
📸 Social Media Favorites: delicate silk embroidery, paper umbrellas, handmade fans, and the museum’s Jiangnan-style courtyard architecture.
🌿 Authentic Atmosphere: combines exhibition halls with an old canal-side setting—perfect for slow walks.
👥 Best For
Culture & craft lovers 🏺
Families with kids (hands-on workshops available) 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers (colorful handicrafts & artisan studios) 📷
Travelers wanting a non-touristy, authentic cultural stop 🌱
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Qinghefang Historical Street area—easy to combine with Hefang Street & Southern Song Imperial Street.
🎫 Free entry, but check for paid workshops (like fan painting or pottery).
⏳ Plan 1–2 hours; if interested in crafts, half a day for the whole cluster.
🛍️ Great place to buy unique souvenirs—authentic, not mass-market.
🌅 Best in the afternoon, then continue to Hefang Street for food & night vibes.

column2: China Animation Museum (中国动漫博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
30 RMB (adult ticket)
Free for kids under 1.2m
🕒 Opening Hours
09:30 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🎬 China’s First National Animation Museum: dedicated to the history and future of animation in China.
🖌 From Ink to Digital: showcases classic Chinese animations, comics, and modern digital productions.
🎮 Interactive Fun: VR experiences, cosplay zones, cartoon dubbing, and kids’ play areas.
🏯 Architectural Highlight: futuristic silver dome + giant glass facade, a landmark building in Hangzhou’s Binjiang district.
📸 Social Media Favorites: cartoon murals, cosplay events, and immersive 3D installations.
👥 Best For
Animation & comic lovers 🎨
Families with kids 👨‍👩‍👧
Young travelers who love cosplay/ACG culture 💫
Visitors looking for a fun indoor spot 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Binjiang District, near the White Horse Lake Ecological Creative City—about 40 min from downtown Hangzhou.
🎫 Tickets can be booked online; some VR/interactive areas may have extra fees.
🎭 Check schedule for cosplay shows, workshops, and seasonal events.
⏳ Plan 2–3 hours here; pair with nearby shopping or creative parks.
🌦 Great choice for a rainy day activity.

column2: China Design Museum (中国国际设计博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉 (special exhibitions may charge ~20–50 RMB)
🕒 Opening Hours
09:30 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🏛 Red Beauty: designed by world-famous architect Álvaro Siza, the museum itself is an architectural icon with striking red walls.
🎨 Design Paradise: focuses on modern and contemporary design—furniture, fashion, industrial products, posters, and digital media.
🌍 Bauhaus Connection: houses the precious Bauhaus collection from Germany, making it one of Asia’s top design hubs.
📸 Social Media Favorites: minimalist corridors, geometric staircases, and bold red exterior—super IG/Xiaohongshu-worthy.
🌿 Campus Vibes: located inside China Academy of Art Xiangshan Campus, surrounded by nature and other cool buildings.
👥 Best For
Art & design lovers 🎨
Architecture & photography fans 📷
Students & creatives seeking inspiration 🌱
Travelers who want a niche, stylish indoor spot ✨
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located at China Academy of Art’s Xiangshan Campus (around 30–40 min from downtown by car/metro + taxi).
🎫 Free entry; reserve online in advance for special exhibitions.
⏳ Allow 1–2 hours inside; can extend by exploring the creative campus around.
🌅 Best photo time: afternoon sunlight on the red walls.
🛍️ Check the museum shop—lots of design books & creative souvenirs.

column2: Zhejiang Science and Technology Museum (浙江省科技馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉 (some special experiences may charge ~20–50 RMB)
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🚀 Interactive Science Heaven: hands-on exhibits in physics, chemistry, biology, and space technology—super fun for kids.
🌍 Earth & Environment Zone: simulations of earthquakes, volcanoes, and climate change.
🛰 Space Exploration: rockets, satellites, and VR experiences about astronomy.
🤖 Robotics & AI: showcases of intelligent tech and future innovations.
📸 Social Media Favorites: futuristic installations, VR experience zones, and giant science models.
👥 Best For
Families with kids 👨‍👩‍👧 (STEM education + entertainment)
Tech & innovation lovers 🤖
Students & young travelers interested in science 🌱
Visitors looking for an indoor activity on rainy/hot days 🌦
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in West Lake Cultural Square, right next to the Zhejiang Natural History Museum—perfect to combine in one trip.
🎫 Reserve free tickets online in advance (Alipay/WeChat mini-programs).
⏳ Allow 2–3 hours; families may want half a day.
🌅 Weekdays are quieter; weekends full of kids.
🍴 Plenty of restaurants & cafes nearby—good for a day-long family outing.

column2: Zhejiang Museum of Natural History (浙江自然博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉 (special exhibitions may charge ~20–50 RMB)
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🦖 Dinosaur Fossils: large skeletons and life-sized models—kids’ favorite.
🐚 Biodiversity of Zhejiang: marine creatures, insects, and plants from local ecosystems.
🌍 Earth & Evolution: geology, minerals, and interactive exhibits explaining Earth’s story.
🐼 Animal Kingdom: dioramas of mammals, birds, and endangered species, including giant panda displays.
📸 Social Media Favorites: giant dinosaur hall, crystal minerals, and immersive animal scenes.
👥 Best For
Families with kids 👨‍👩‍👧 (super educational + fun)
Nature lovers 🌿
Science & geology enthusiasts 🔬
Travelers looking for an indoor activity on hot/rainy days 🌦️
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Main branch at West Lake Cultural Square (Wulin area), easily combined with shopping or food nearby.
🎫 Free tickets can be booked online (Alipay/WeChat mini-programs).
⏳ Allow 2–3 hours if visiting with kids—lots of interactive zones.
🌅 Weekdays are less crowded; weekends often full of families.
🍴 Plenty of cafes & restaurants around West Lake Cultural Square—great for a full-day outing.

column2: Han Meilin Art Museum (韩美林艺术馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🎨 Master’s Collection: Han Meilin is one of China’s most renowned contemporary artists, known for his playful animal paintings, calligraphy, and sculpture (he designed the Beijing 2008 Olympic mascots!).
🐼 Iconic Animal Art: pandas, roosters, horses, and cats—full of vitality and humor.
🏯 Modern + Traditional Space: minimalist architecture with Chinese garden elements, surrounded by bamboo groves near the West Lake.
🌿 Peaceful Atmosphere: less touristy, offering a calm art appreciation environment.
📸 Social Media Favorites: panda-themed artworks, outdoor sculptures, and the airy glass exhibition halls.
👥 Best For
Art & design lovers 🎨
Families with kids (fun animal artworks!) 👨‍👩‍👧
Couples on a slow cultural date 💕
Travelers who want something beyond the usual West Lake itinerary 🌿
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near West Lake (southwest area, close to Zoo station). Easy to combine with Hangzhou Zoo or Taiziwan Park.
🎫 Free entry but check for temporary exhibitions that may require registration.
📷 Photography is allowed in most areas—lots of IG-friendly corners.
🌅 Go in the morning for soft light streaming into the glass halls.
🧧 Great place to buy unique art souvenirs (prints, small sculptures).

column2: Hangzhou Museum (杭州博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🏛 City’s Own Museum: tells the story of Hangzhou’s 2,000+ years of history, from ancient Qiantang to modern Hangzhou.
🎨 Southern Song Capital: highlights from when Hangzhou was the capital of the Southern Song Dynasty—calligraphy, paintings, celadon, and daily life artifacts.
🏯 Local Flavor: unique exhibits on West Lake culture, tea, silk, and merchant traditions.
📍 Convenient Location: near Wushan Square and Hefang Street, perfect to combine with old town walks.
📸 Social Media Favorites: Southern Song celadon, panoramic city history timeline, and modern minimalist exhibition halls.
👥 Best For
History & culture lovers 🏯
First-time visitors who want a quick intro to Hangzhou 🌿
Families (interactive displays for kids) 👨‍👩‍👧
Travelers exploring Hefang Street & Southern Song Imperial Street 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Shangcheng District, 15 min walk from Hefang Street.
🎫 Free entry, just reserve online (Alipay/WeChat).
🌦 Great option for rainy/hot days since it’s fully indoors.
🕰️ Allow 1–2 hours—compact but very informative.
🍵 Combine with a Hefang Street tea stop for a cultural + foodie afternoon.

column2: China National Tea Museum (中国茶叶博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🍵 Only National Tea Museum in China: fully dedicated to the history, culture, and art of tea.
🌿 Scenic Location: surrounded by Longjing tea fields and bamboo groves—museum + nature combined.
🏺 Immersive Exhibits: tea history, utensils, world tea culture, and modern innovations.
☕ Interactive Experience: tea-tasting sessions, seasonal tea-picking workshops, calligraphy, and even tea ceremonies.
📸 Social Media Favorites: elegant teahouse courtyards, minimalist exhibitions, tea terraces outside the museum.
👥 Best For
Tea lovers & culture seekers 🍃
Families with kids (fun + educational) 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers (traditional teahouse aesthetic) 📷
Travelers who want more than sightseeing—a lifestyle experience ✨
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located in Shuangfeng area, near Longjing Village, 20 min drive from downtown Hangzhou.
🎫 Admission free; workshops & tastings have extra costs (book online or on-site).
🌸 Best season: March–April during tea harvest—fields outside come alive.
🍵 Combine with Longjing Village, Meijiawu, or Jiuxi for a perfect “tea day trip.”
🛍️ Tea sold inside is authentic but pricier than buying from farmers directly.

column2: Southern Song Official Kiln Museum (南宋官窑博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🏺 Unique Theme: the only museum in China built directly over the excavation site of the Southern Song Dynasty imperial kilns.
🎨 Celadon Heaven: showcases delicate bluish-green porcelain, famous for its jade-like glaze and subtle elegance.
🏯 Living History: walk among preserved kiln ruins while learning how porcelain was fired 800+ years ago.
🌿 Quiet & Niche: much less crowded than other Hangzhou museums—perfect for a slow cultural afternoon.
📸 Social Media Favorites: jade-green celadon bowls, ancient kiln ruins, minimalist aesthetic displays.
👥 Best For
History & culture lovers 🏛️
Art & design enthusiasts 🎨
Photographers (celadon details are stunning) 📷
Travelers wanting a niche, off-the-beaten-path experience 🌱
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located south of West Lake, near China National Silk Museum—easy to combine in one trip.
🎫 Admission free, but special exhibitions may require a small fee.
📷 Museum lighting is soft—great for detail photography, but bring a good camera for celadon close-ups.
🌸 If you’re into Song Dynasty culture, pair with China National Tea Museum or Silk Museum for a full “Song heritage” theme day.
🧧 A great spot for rainy days—indoor, quiet, and atmospheric.

column2: China National Silk Museum (中国丝绸博物馆)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 （closed on Mondays）
✨ Highlights
🧵 World’s Largest Silk Museum: dedicated to 5,000 years of silk history and culture.
👘 Silk Road Stories: exhibitions trace how Hangzhou silk once traveled the world.
🎨 Fashion Meets Tradition: rotating displays of silk garments from ancient robes to modern haute couture.
🏯 Scenic Location: at the foot of Yuhuang Mountain, near West Lake’s south side—culture + nature combo.
📸 Social Media Favorites: elegant silk robes, colorful textile patterns, and immersive silk weaving installations.
👥 Best For
Fashion & design lovers 👗
History & culture explorers 🏛️
Families (interactive exhibitions for kids) 👨‍👩‍👧
Travelers wanting indoor activities on hot/rainy days 🌦️
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 10–15 min drive from Leifeng Pagoda & Prince Bay Park—easy to add into a West Lake south line itinerary.
🎫 Admission is free, but check online for special exhibitions that may require tickets.
📷 Photography allowed in most areas—perfect for IG & Xiaohongshu posts.
🌸 Best season: spring & autumn, so you can combine with nearby outdoor attractions.
🛍️ There’s a small shop with silk scarves, ties, and gifts—great souvenirs.

column2: China National Tea Museum – West Lake Longjing Branch (中国茶叶博物馆·西湖龙井馆区)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
09:00 – 17:00 (closed on Mondays)
✨ Highlights
🍵 Only National Tea Museum in China: dedicated to tea history, culture, and art, located in the heart of Longjing tea fields.
🌿 Immersive Tea Experience: exhibitions on tea varieties, utensils, brewing methods, and global tea culture.
🏯 Scenic Location: surrounded by tea plantations and bamboo forests—perfect for combining culture with nature.
☕ Interactive Activities: tea tasting, DIY tea making, calligraphy, and seasonal tea-picking workshops.
📸 Social Media Favorites: teahouse courtyards, cultural displays, and tea field panoramas outside the museum.
👥 Best For
Tea lovers & culture seekers 🍃
Families (fun + educational for kids) 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers (traditional teahouse vibes) 📷
Travelers who want to go beyond sightseeing into Chinese lifestyle ✨
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near Longjing Village, 20 min from downtown Hangzhou by car.
🌸 Best time: spring (tea harvest season) for lively field activities.
🎫 Free entry, but tea-tasting and workshops have extra costs.
🍵 Combine with a visit to Longjing Village or Meijiawu for a tea culture day.
🛍️ Tea sold at the museum is authentic but usually pricier than local farmers’.

column2: Longwu Tea Village (龙坞茶村)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉 （茶馆体验 50–200 RMB/人；购买茶叶价格依品质 200–1000+ RMB/500g）
🕒 Opening Hours
Village open all day
Tea houses & restaurants usually 09:00 – 20:00
✨ Highlights
🍵 “Ten-Thousand Mu Tea Sea”: the largest Longjing tea production area in Hangzhou, vast green terraces stretching endlessly.
🌿 Authentic Tea Life: less commercial than Longjing Village or Meijiawu—this is where you feel real tea farmer vibes.
🚶 Scenic Walks: paths run through rolling tea fields, bamboo groves, and village roads—perfect for hiking & photography.
🥘 Rustic Farm Meals: countryside restaurants serve tea-infused Hangzhou dishes (Longjing shrimp, tea chicken).
📸 Social Media Favorites: panoramic drone shots of tea terraces, tea-picking photos in spring, sipping tea overlooking the fields.
👥 Best For
Tea enthusiasts & culture lovers 🍃
Hikers & slow travelers 🚶
Photographers looking for epic green terrace shots 📷
Families & groups seeking a countryside day trip 👨‍👩‍👧
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 40 min by car from downtown Hangzhou; few direct buses, so Didi/chartered car is best.
🌸 Best season: March–April (tea-picking season); May–June also lush green.
💸 Buy tea directly from farmers—better value than city shops.
👟 Wear comfy shoes if you plan to hike deeper into the terraces.
🍵 Great to combine with Meijiawu or Yunqi Bamboo Path for a full-day eco & tea tour.

column2: Yunqi Bamboo Path (云栖竹径)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best in the morning or late afternoon when light filters through the bamboo)
✨ Highlights
🎋 Bamboo Wonderland: a quiet valley with dense bamboo groves on both sides, creating a green tunnel effect.
🌫 Zen Atmosphere: mist and sunlight streaming through the bamboo make it feel like stepping into a movie scene.
🚶 Scenic Trail: stone paths lead you through several kilometers of peaceful bamboo forest, perfect for slow walking.
🦋 Nature Therapy: birdsong, fresh air, and the sound of wind in the bamboo—super healing.
📸 Social Media Favorites: long bamboo corridors, sunlight-and-shadow shots, minimalistic “green world” aesthetic.
👥 Best For
Nature lovers 🍃
Couples (romantic & photogenic walk) 💕
Photographers 📷 (soft light + bamboo tunnel = dreamy shots)
Travelers who want a non-touristy, calming spot 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 30 min from downtown Hangzhou by car; easy to combine with Jiuxi (九溪烟树) and Meijiawu tea fields.
👟 Wear comfy walking shoes—paths are paved but can be slippery after rain.
🌅 Best time: early morning for mist, or golden hour for dramatic light.
🧢 Bring mosquito repellent in summer.
🍵 After the walk, visit nearby tea villages (Meijiawu or Longjing) for a perfect bamboo + tea experience.

column2: Meijiawu Tea Culture Village (梅家坞茶文化村)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry (tea house tasting usually 50–200 RMB per person; tea leaves for sale vary from 200–1000+ RMB per 500g depending on quality)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 20:00 (teahouses & restaurants)
Village & tea fields are accessible all day 🌿
✨ Highlights
🍵 Longjing Tea Capital: one of the core production areas for authentic Longjing (Dragon Well) green tea.
🌿 Tea Culture Experience: join a tea farmer for leaf-picking, pan-frying, and tasting.
🚶 Tea Field Walks: endless terraces, bamboo forests, and mountain trails—like a living tea painting.
🥟 Farmhouse Cuisine: rustic Hangzhou dishes paired with fresh tea, e.g., Longjing shrimp 🍤.
📸 Social Media Favorites: panoramic tea terraces, hand-picking tea photos, sipping tea on bamboo chairs with a mountain backdrop.
👥 Best For
Tea lovers 🍵
Families & groups looking for an interactive cultural day 👨‍👩‍👧
Couples (romantic hillside teahouses) 💕
Travelers seeking a countryside escape near Hangzhou 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 30 min from downtown Hangzhou by car; Didi or tourist shuttle bus available.
🌸 Best season: March–April for tea-picking season; spring is the liveliest time.
💸 Buy tea directly from local farmers—better price & freshness than city shops.
🍴 Don’t miss farmhouse-style meals; try tea-infused dishes for the full experience.
👟 Bring comfy shoes if you want to hike through plantations (some trails are steep).

column2: Faxi Temple (法喜寺)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry (donation for incense ~20–50 RMB)
🕒 Opening Hours
07:00 – 18:00
✨ Highlights
🏯 Ancient Buddhist Temple: dating back to the Northern Song Dynasty, hidden in the mountains near West Lake.
🧧 Most Popular Wish-Granting Temple: locals and young travelers come here to pray for career, love, and exams—viral on Xiaohongshu.
🌿 Serene Setting: surrounded by forest and tea fields, away from the city buzz.
🕯 Ritual Experience: light incense, make a wish, and hang a red prayer tag—super photogenic.
📸 Social Media Favorites: red wishing tags under green trees, temple halls in mist, and sunrise views after morning prayers.
👥 Best For
Spiritual seekers & culture lovers 🙏
Young travelers wanting to “pray for good luck” 🌸
Couples (many come to pray for relationships 💕)
Photographers (red prayer tags = iconic shots) 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 20 min drive from West Lake; also reachable by Didi or bus.
🎫 Incense and prayer tags are available inside—cashless payments accepted.
🌅 Morning visits = fewer crowds & softer light; avoid public holidays (very packed).
🍵 Can combine with Longjing Village for tea tasting after temple visit.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—the temple complex has steps and uphill paths.

column2: Nine Creeks and Eighteen Gullies (九溪十八涧)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best in early morning or after rain)
✨ Highlights
🌊 Hidden Stream Paradise: 9 main creeks weave through 18 gullies, forming a natural water maze.
🌫 Misty Wonderland: after rain, fog rises above the forest, creating a dreamy Chinese painting vibe.
🚶 Scenic Hiking Path: stone trails & stepping stones across streams—perfect for light hiking & photos.
🌸 Seasonal Beauty: tea fields in spring, lush greenery in summer, maple colors in autumn, crystal-clear water in winter.
📸 Social Media Favorites: stepping on rocks across creeks, reflections under maple trees, hikers in bamboo groves.
👥 Best For
Nature lovers 🍃
Hikers & adventure seekers 👟
Couples looking for a quiet romantic walk 💕
Photographers who love misty mountain vibes 📷
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 20–30 min drive from West Lake; public transport + short walk also possible.
👟 Wear non-slip shoes—paths can be slippery after rain.
🌅 Best time: spring (tea harvest) & autumn (maple leaves).
🧢 Bring mosquito repellent in summer, and water/snacks since facilities are minimal.
🍵 Can combine with Longjing Village or Yunqi Bamboo Path for a half/full-day eco trip.

column2: Shili Langdang (十里琅珰)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best time: morning to afternoon; avoid late evening as trails are unlit)
✨ Highlights
🌿 Mountain Ridge Trail: a 10-li (about 5 km) scenic route connecting tea fields, bamboo forests, and mountain views.
🍃 Secret Hiking Spot: compared with West Lake crowds, here you’ll find tranquil nature and very few tourists.
🍵 Tea Field Vistas: overlooks Longjing tea plantations and rural villages—super photogenic.
🌸 Seasonal Charm: azaleas in spring, lush bamboo in summer, golden forests in autumn, crisp mountain air in winter.
📸 Social Media Favorites: bamboo groves with sunlight filtering in, hikers walking stone paths, panoramic mountain views.
👥 Best For
Hikers & outdoor lovers 👟
Photographers & creators 📷
Couples/friends who enjoy active adventures 🌸
Travelers who want to go “beyond West Lake” 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Trailheads connect with Longjing Village, Jiuxi (九溪烟树), and Yunqi Bamboo Path (云栖竹径)—great to combine into a loop.
👟 Wear proper walking shoes—trails are natural stone and can be slippery after rain.
🧢 Bring water & light snacks—no shops inside the mountain area.
🌅 Best time: morning for fresh air & soft light; autumn is the most colorful season.
🐦 Keep an eye out for wild birds & butterflies—nature here is very lively.

column2: Longjing Village (龙井村 / Longjing Tea Village)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry (just pay for tea tastings or meals; Longjing tea 50–200 RMB per pot depending on quality)
🕒 Opening Hours
10:00 – 20:00 （teahouses & restaurants）
Villages & tea fields are open all day 🌿
✨ Highlights
🍵 Home of Dragon Well Tea: birthplace of China’s most famous green tea, with terraced fields stretching across the hills.
🌿 Tea Tasting Experience: sit in a rustic teahouse overlooking the plantations while sipping fresh Longjing tea.
🚶 Tea Field Walks: stone paths wind through lush plantations—great for photos & casual hikes.
📸 Social Media Favorites: panoramic shots of tea terraces, locals hand-picking leaves in spring, sipping tea on bamboo chairs.
🌸 Seasonal Vibes: March–April is tea-picking season; super lively and cultural.
👥 Best For
Tea lovers & culture explorers 🍵
Couples (romantic hillside teahouses) 💕
Photographers 📷
Travelers wanting a “slow Hangzhou” countryside escape 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 About 20 min from West Lake by car; buses & shared bikes also possible.
🍵 Spring (March–April) is the best time to visit—fresh tea harvest & blossoms.
💸 Buy tea directly from locals—often better quality & price than downtown shops.
🌅 Go in late afternoon for golden light over the tea terraces.
👟 Wear comfy shoes if planning to hike through the plantations.

column2: Nine Creeks and Misty Trees (九溪烟树)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best in early morning or after rain when mist rises)
✨ Highlights
🌿 Hidden Paradise: a quiet valley south of West Lake, where nine creeks merge and flow under ancient trees.
🌫 Misty Vibes: after rain, the whole area is covered in fog and feels like a Chinese ink painting.
🚶 Scenic Hiking Trail: stone paths, wooden bridges, and streams—perfect for a 1–2 hour nature walk.
🌸 Seasonal Beauty: azaleas in spring, lush green in summer, golden leaves in autumn, clear streams in winter.
📸 Social Media Favorites: stepping stones across the creek, misty mornings, couples walking under maple trees.
👥 Best For
Hikers & nature lovers 🍃
Couples seeking a quiet romantic stroll 💕
Photographers & content creators 📷
Travelers who want an escape from West Lake crowds 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
🚕 About 20 min drive from West Lake; public buses also available but less direct.
👟 Wear hiking shoes—stone paths can be slippery after rain.
🌅 Best time: early morning or on cloudy days for the misty “smoky tree” look.
🍵 Combine with nearby Longjing Tea Village—hike + tea tasting = perfect half-day trip.
🧢 Summer can be humid; bring water & mosquito repellent.

column2: Yue Fei Temple (岳王庙 / 岳飞庙)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
25 RMB (adult ticket)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 17:00
✨ Highlights
🏯 Historic Shrine: built in memory of General Yue Fei, China’s national hero of the Song Dynasty.
✒️ Famous Calligraphy: the four-character motto “精忠报国 (Serve the Country with Utmost Loyalty)” carved on stone tablets—perfect photo spot.
⚔️ Cultural Symbol: tells the story of Yue Fei’s loyalty and tragic fate, a key part of Chinese patriotic culture.
🌿 Serene Courtyard: traditional halls, red pillars, and ancient cypress trees create a solemn yet peaceful vibe.
📸 Social Media Favorites: Yue Fei’s statue, stone inscriptions, and the kneeling iron statues of traitors (Qin Hui & others).
👥 Best For
History & culture lovers 🏯
Travelers interested in Chinese heroes & legends ⚔️
Families with teens (educational spot) 👨‍👩‍👧
Anyone doing a full “cultural West Lake loop”
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located at the north side of West Lake, near Broken Bridge and Bai Causeway—easy to add into a walking route.
🎫 Tickets available on-site or online mini-programs.
🧧 It’s a solemn site—keep voices low, especially near the main hall.
🌅 Visit in the morning to avoid crowds; afternoons have softer light for photography.
📚 Recommended to read a short intro on Yue Fei’s story before visiting for deeper context.

column2: Leifeng Pagoda (雷峰塔)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
40 RMB (adult ticket)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 20:30 (last entry ~19:30, night view highly recommended 🌙)
✨ Highlights
🏯 Legendary Pagoda: famous for the “Legend of the White Snake” (白蛇传), one of China’s most romantic folk tales.
🌅 Best Sunset Spot: from the top, you get panoramic views of West Lake, Su Causeway, and city skyline.
🎇 Night Lights: beautifully illuminated at night, reflecting on the lake like a painting.
🖼 Historic Meets Modern: original pagoda dates back to 975 AD; the current one rebuilt with glass elevators & exhibits.
📸 Social Media Favorites: sunset shots from the top, night reflections, and storytelling murals inside.
👥 Best For
Couples 💕 (romantic vibes from the White Snake legend)
History & culture lovers 🏯
Photographers & IG creators 📷
First-time visitors to Hangzhou (a must-see landmark)
column7:
💡 Tips
🎫 Ticket can be booked online via Alipay/WeChat mini-programs.
🌅 Best time: go around 17:00 → explore inside → catch sunset from the top → stay for night lights.
📍 Combine with Huagang Park (花港观鱼) or Jingci Temple (净慈寺) nearby for a half-day walk.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—though there’s an elevator, some stairs are unavoidable.
🧧 Locals say visiting brings good fortune—many light incense at Jingci Temple next door.

column2: Yuhu Bay (浴鹄湾)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best time: morning for mist, or late afternoon for soft light)
✨ Highlights
🌿 Idyllic Water Scene: winding streams, willow trees, lotus ponds, and small stone bridges—like walking into an ink painting.
🦆 Tranquil Wildlife: herons, ducks, and fish make the bay lively yet peaceful.
🌸 Seasonal Charm: peach blossoms in spring, lotus in summer, golden reeds in autumn, misty reflections in winter.
🚶 Hidden West Lake: far less crowded than Broken Bridge or Leifeng Pagoda, perfect for slow travel vibes.
📸 Social Media Favorites: arched bridges mirrored in water, willow-lined trails, mist floating over the bay.
👥 Best For
Slow travelers & nature lovers 🍃
Couples seeking a romantic walk 💕
Photographers 📷 (misty mornings & reflections are dreamy)
Locals on chill weekend strolls 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located near Yanggong Causeway, easy to combine with Maojiabu, Wuguitan, and Huagang Park in a walking/cycling loop.
🌅 Best time: early morning (mist + quiet) or sunset (golden water reflections).
🍵 Bring a thermos of Longjing tea—many locals sip tea while enjoying the views.
🧢 In summer, bring mosquito repellent—wetlands attract bugs.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—stone paths may be slippery after rain.

column2: Wuguitan (乌龟潭)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best time: morning & late afternoon)
✨ Highlights
🐢 Legendary Pond: named after turtle-shaped rocks & legends of turtles in the water.
🌿 Hidden Gem of West Lake: tucked away near Yang Causeway, much quieter than Broken Bridge or Leifeng Pagoda.
🌸 Seasonal Charm: peach blossoms in spring, lotus in summer, maple colors in autumn, misty reflections in winter.
🚶 Zen Vibes: stone bridges, winding paths, and shaded groves make it perfect for slow walks.
📸 Social Media Favorites: turtle rock reflections, willow-lined paths, calm water shots.
👥 Best For
Travelers seeking a non-touristy corner of West Lake 🌱
Couples who want a peaceful date walk 💕
Photographers (misty mornings = dream shots) 📷
Locals on weekend strolls 🚶
column7:
💡 Tips
📍 Located along Yanggong Causeway—easy to combine with Maojiabu and Huagang Park in a loop.
🌅 Go early morning for quiet vibes & misty scenery.
👟 Wear comfy shoes—paths are natural stone and slightly uneven.
🧺 Bring light snacks or tea—perfect for a short chill stop.
🎣 Sometimes you’ll see locals fishing—adds to the authentic Hangzhou vibe.

column2: Maojiabu Village (杭州茅家埠风景区)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry (just pay for food/tea if dining in local teahouses or restaurants)
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (restaurants & teahouses usually 10:00 – 21:00)
✨ Highlights
🌾 Pastoral West Lake: unlike the busy Su Causeway, Maojiabu feels like a hidden countryside corner of West Lake with lotus ponds, willows, and small bridges.
🐟 Water Village Vibes: rustic stone paths, bamboo groves, and streams create a painting-like atmosphere.
🍵 Lakeside Teahouses: perfect for sipping Longjing tea while watching fishermen & birds.
🚶 Best City Walk Spot: a top choice for slow travelers—quiet, photogenic, and close to nature.
📸 Social Media Favorites: lotus in summer, misty mornings, and teahouse terraces overlooking the water.
👥 Best For
Slow travelers who want “hidden Hangzhou” 🌿
Couples on a romantic, quiet date 💕
Photographers/creators (mist, lotus, rustic tea houses) 📷
Families looking for relaxed weekend vibes 👨‍👩‍👧
column7:
💡 Tips
🚲 Best explored by bike or walking from West Lake’s south side—it connects to other scenic trails.
🍵 Try local teahouses like Maojiabu Teahouse—authentic vibes, less touristy than lakeside cafés.
📍 Go in the morning for mist + calm water; evenings are also beautiful with soft light.
🧺 Bring mosquito repellent in summer.
🛶 It’s near Yanggong Causeway—perfect to combine into a half-day walk or cycle route.

column2: Hangzhou Baita Park (杭州白塔公园)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
06:00 – 18:00 （部分区域全天开放）
✨ Highlights
🚂 Railway + Old Bridges: famous for its century-old railway bridge over the Qiantang River, with industrial-meets-historic vibes.
🌿 Slow Riverside Walk: peaceful trails along the riverbank, perfect for escaping the downtown bustle.
📸 Photography Hotspot: red railway bridge + white pagoda = niche Instagram/Xiaohongshu vibes.
🏯 Cultural Touch: named after the historic white pagoda near the river; the area blends Hangzhou’s industrial heritage with natural scenery.
🌅 Sunset Views: amazing river sunsets with silhouettes of the bridge—most recommended time.
👥 Best For
📷 Photographers & content creators (retro/industrial style)
🚶 Travelers who love niche & non-touristy spots
Couples looking for a quiet riverside walk
Locals on weekend strolls
column7:
💡 Tips
🚇 Take Metro Line 4 → Baita Bridge Station, then walk to the park.
🌅 Best time: late afternoon → sunset for golden light on the bridge.
🧺 Bring snacks/drinks—few vendors inside.
👟 Wear comfy shoes; paths are flat but you may want to explore along the riverbank.
📸 If you like urban exploration shots, the railway bridge & riverside tracks are must-shoot spots.

column2: Prince Bay Park (太子湾公园)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry 🎉
🕒 Opening Hours
06:00 – 18:00 （春季高峰可能会延长）
✨ Highlights
🌷 Tulip Wonderland: every March–April, the park bursts into colors with millions of tulips and cherry blossoms—IG hot spot.
🌸 Romantic Sakura Season: cherry trees lining the paths make it one of the best spring date spots in Hangzhou.
🌿 European Garden Vibes: landscaped lawns, streams, and arched bridges feel like walking into a fairy tale.
🦆 Lake + Wildlife: swans and ducks add to the serene atmosphere.
📸 Social Media Favorites: tulip sea in spring, cherry blossom archways, lovers’ bridge reflections.
👥 Best For
Couples 🌸💕 (Hangzhou’s top proposal/engagement photo spot)
Families 👨‍👩‍👧 (kids love the flower fields & ponds)
Photographers 📷 (especially in spring)
Travelers who love slow strolls & picnics 🍃
column7:
💡 Tips
🌸 Best season: March–April (tulips + cherry blossoms), but also pleasant year-round.
🚶 Go early morning on weekends to avoid crowds.
📍 Bring a mat/snacks for a mini picnic—locals do this a lot.
🚇 Take Metro Line 1 → Longxiangqiao, then a short taxi/bike ride.
📱 Don’t miss the arch bridge over the stream—the most viral Xiaohongshu photo spot.

column2: Hangzhou Botanical Garden (杭州植物园)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
10 RMB (very budget-friendly)
🕒 Opening Hours
07:30 – 17:30
✨ Highlights
🌸 Four-Season Beauty: cherry blossoms in spring, lotus & green shades in summer, red maple in autumn, plum blossoms in winter.
🌿 Secret Picnic Spot: wide lawns under camphor trees—local families bring mats & snacks.
🌼 Flower Photography Paradise: seasonal floral exhibitions (peonies, tulips, orchids) draw many photo lovers.
🍵 Tea Culture: located right next to Longjing tea plantations; you can easily combine a garden walk with tea tasting.
📸 Social Media Favorites: cherry blossom avenue in March, maple grove in November, lotus pond bridges in summer.
👥 Best For
Families 👨‍👩‍👧 (kids can run safely on the lawns)
Couples on a casual date 🌸
Photographers 📷
Travelers seeking a relaxing, non-touristy spot 🍃
column7:
💡 Tips
🧺 Pack light snacks & drinks—locals love doing mini-picnics here.
📍 Combine with a visit to nearby Lingfeng Mountain and Longjing Village for tea & panoramic views.
🌅 Best time: early morning or late afternoon for soft light and fewer crowds.
🎟️ Only cashless payment at the entrance (Alipay/WeChat Pay).
🐦 Birdsong makes the walk extra calming—bring earphones only if you want background music.

column2: Xixi National Wetland Park (西溪国家湿地公园)
column6:
💰 Average Cost
80 RMB (standard ticket, includes main scenic spots; boat rides extra 60–100 RMB)
🕒 Opening Hours
08:00 – 17:30 (last entry usually 16:30)
✨ Highlights
🚣‍♀️ Traditional Boat Ride: glide through bamboo waterways and lotus ponds—super photogenic.
🦆 Wildlife & Bird Watching: one of China’s best urban wetlands, perfect for spotting migratory birds.
🌾 Fisherman’s Life Show: experience reed-pulling, fishing, and local folk culture.
🌿 Green Escape: a rare quiet retreat just 30 min from downtown Hangzhou, often described as “the city’s backyard paradise.”
📸 Social Media Spots: Lotus Pond boardwalk, Misty Water Pavilions, and the iconic water village bridges.
👥 Best For
Nature lovers 🍃
Families with kids (educational + fun) 👨‍👩‍👧
Couples looking for a slow, romantic day 🌸
Travelers wanting a break from city crowds 🚶

Hangzhou isn’t just West Lake! 🌿 At Xixi Wetland you can drift on a wooden boat, watch egrets fly over lotus ponds, and feel like you stepped into an ancient water painting. Perfect for a slow afternoon escape.
column7:
💡 Tips
🎫 Book tickets online (Alipay/WeChat mini-program) to skip queues.
🚣 If time is short, take a boat ride + short walk—it covers the best views.
📍 Go early morning for misty vibes, fewer people, and great photography.
🍵 Combine with a tea stop nearby in Longjing Village (龙井村), just 15 min away by car.
🧢 Bring a hat & mosquito repellent in summer; wetlands can get humid.

column2: Hangzhou West Lake（杭州西湖）
column6:
💰 Average Cost
Free entry (some individual spots like boat rides or pagodas may charge 20–50 RMB)
🕒 Opening Hours
24 hours (best time: sunrise & sunset; boat rentals usually 8:00–17:00)
✨ Highlights
🌅 Sunset on Su Causeway: the most photogenic spot, especially during golden hour.
🚴 Cycling Loop: rent a bike and circle the 15km lake path; tree-lined avenues and lotus in summer make it feel like a movie scene.
⛵ Boat Ride to Three Pools Mirroring the Moon: iconic night view printed on the 1 RMB note.
🌸 Seasonal Charm: cherry blossoms in spring, lotus in summer, red maples in autumn, misty lake in winter.
📸 Social Media Favorites: Broken Bridge (断桥残雪), Leifeng Pagoda (雷峰塔), music fountain at night.
👥 Best For
Couples on romantic walks 🌸
Families (kids love the boat rides) 👨‍👩‍👧
Photographers & content creators 📷
Travelers who enjoy slow travel & nature lovers 🍃
column7:
💡 Tips
🚴 Rent a shared bike (Alipay/WeChat app) for less than 2 RMB/hour; cycling is the most efficient and scenic way.
🌅 Arrive early in the morning for fewer crowds and magical mist views.
🍵 Pair your walk with a stop at a lakeside teahouse (like Hu Pan Ju) for Longjing tea.
📍 Combine with nearby cultural spots: Lingyin Temple, Guo’s Villa, and Hefang Street for a full-day itinerary.
🧾 Bring cashless payment (Alipay/WeChat Pay) as many kiosks don’t take cards.

column2: Dahuaxing Temple 深圳大华兴寺
